awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Broadening Secure Mobile Software Development (SMSD) Through Curriculum and Faculty Development
awd_abstract_narration:
The computing landscape is rapidly moving towards mobile computing, and security threats to mobile devices are also keeping up pace. Most security vulnerabilities should be addressed in the mobile software development phase; however, many development professionals are not aware of the importance of mitigating security vulnerabilities, and lack the requisite security knowledge and skills to prevent them at the development stage. The combination of the prevalence of mobile devices and the rapid growth of mobile threats has resulted in a shortage of mobile-security professionals. Education for secure mobile application development is in big demand in IT fields. More and more schools are teaching mobile application development or related courses. However, educational materials and curricula focusing on Secure Mobile Software Development (SMSD) are still sparse. In this project, three universities with prior collaboration records and complementary expertise in mobile security and computing education: Tuskegee University, Kennesaw State University, and Worcester Polytechnic Institute, are collaboratively building research and education capacity in secure mobile software development through three venues: (1) curriculum development and enhancement with eight transferrable learning modules including companion hands-on labs on mobile coding; (2) institutional and faculty development with annual onsite faculty summer workshops and online webinars; and (3) an innovative open source SMSD API plugin for real world Android Studio IDE.

The investigators are developing instructional materials, including eight transferable modules with hands-on labs that cover key topics in SMSD, an open source SMSD API plugin for the popular Android Studio IDE, as well as integrating the modules into existing computer science and information assurance courses such as Mobile Security, and hosting workshops and webinars to disseminate the curriculum materials to faculty at other institutions. Through these efforts, the project aims to: (1) build institutional capacity on curricula, student learning, and faculty collaboration and development; (2) broaden participation of minority students in SMSD; and (3) build the capacity in SMSD education among the academic community nationwide with the modular nature of the developed materials.

por.por_cntn:
This project addressed the needs for national mobile-security professionals through building capacity in secure mobile software development with effective, engaging and investigative approaches. The project built capacity in Secure Mobile Software Development (SMSD) in curriculum, faculty, and workforce development. This project developed lecture topics on SMSD such as threats and vulnerabilities in mobile application, secure development in mobile computing, using cryptography in mobile computing, security policy and governance, etc. This project also developed an innovative open source SMSD API plugin for real world Android Studio IDE. A collection of hands-on labs and learning module has been developed on Data Sanitization for input validation, Data Sanitization for output encoding, SQL Injections, Data protection, Secure Inter-Process Communication (IPC), Secure mobile database, Unintended Data Leakage, and Access Control. The eight learning modules on SMSD and four learning modules on open source SMSD API plugin were developed and integrated into curricula in Tuskegee University, Kennesaw State University, and Worcester Polytechnic Institute, which built institutional capacity in participating institutions. Positive feedback from students demonstrated improved learning and increased interests through using developed pedagogical materials. A self-published eBook was developed and published in project website and openlibrary website for the community. This project sponsored two summer faculty development workshops and one virtual faculty development workshop to build faculty expertise on secure mobile software development. The faculty development workshops provide participating faculty with sufficient training so that they could go back and infuse secure mobile software development concepts in their respective teaching areas. Faculty who participated in these workshops have built their expertise and received necessary materials infused into teaching at their home institutions.

 

Moreover, project results were disseminated to communities of interests through peer- reviewed journal papers, conference showcase, faculty workshops, major education conferences in computing such as Special Interest Groups in Computer Science Education (SIGCSE) and IEEE International Symposium on Networks, Computers and Communications (ISNCC), and a self-published eBook. Additionally, our project has increased partnership among diverse institutions as evidenced by collaborative publications, proposals, and funded grants. The project also inspired multidisciplinary applied research and student research in mobile security, software security, and healthcare. In summary, this project has positively impacted students at Tuskegee University, Kennesaw State University, and Worcester Polytechnic Institute. This project has also helped to build research capacity of student, faculty, institution, and the surrounding community.
